p: Figure 2shows the microbial cells before and after treatment with C. zeylanicum essential oil. The cell appearances were changed upon treatment, likely through altering outer cell envelopes. The untreated E. coli cells have their typical striated wall structures ( Figure 2(a)), and the differences between the control cells and the treated ones can be easily observed in the rod morphology ( Figure 2(b)). It seems that the essential oil of C. zeylanicum has the ability to disrupt the membrane of E. coli cells and facilitate intracellular compounds leakage, as indicated by the presence of malformed and sunken cell shapes. In fact, the essential oil resulted in a high cell disruption and subsequently greater cell lysis degrees in E. coli. The strained wall structures of L. innocua cells were changed after treatment with the essential oil, as well (Figures 2(c) and 2(d)). The oil caused deformity in the cell surfaces, and the treated L. innocua cells had wrinkled and irregular cellular shapes.
